content.title: Email Composition
content.layoutDescription: Email composition window with recipient and subject fields, main text area, and formatting options.
content.visibleText:
CEO feedback

Ben New (devfactory.com), Nouman Shah (devfactory.com), David Schwartz (devfactory.com), Joe Conley (devfactory.com), Marcelo Skaba (devfactory.com), Chris Hornby (devfactory.com)

CEO feedback

Their unfiltered view:

They believe Q2 is going much better than Q1.
They appreciate the customer/business focus, the transparency (weekly calls), and the alignment.
Andy P asked them to grade each slot on how we were doing. All slots got a B, with the exception of Jigsaw, which got a C (Q1 shadows results; Kathy's looking at this as 0.5M to get some upgrades, not even all).

They think we're slow
Don't let the B grades fool you...
The core message is that the ice cube is melting too fast and that we need to be much faster at doing the grunt work (defense, cost) so we can start doing AI features.
Joe's vision here is simpleâ€”take only a few companies or increase his investment in the products until he sees increased pace and quality...
Platforms upgrades should had led us not by our week, not months.
Acquisitions should be faster. we should be able to complete in the first 90 days the import, cost optimizations, high prio defense work and build one top-down AI feature.

They are moving work to external companies
DR is building 2-3 new products (e.g. PlanAI or BSS Magic) with external companies; others are building AI pilots with external companies, too, or with their internal resources.
They're trapped in a way: CEOs are expected to build AI features, but their budget barely allows them to keep the products afloat, which forces them to go outside.

It's unacceptable to have products break due to retired dependencies (e.g. Playbooks)
When they send a product to Central, they expect us to keep it running.
It's not a problem of speed; we simply cannot ignore them until they blow up.

I don't think it matters if this is fair or accurate, The important part is to accept the business will only continue to exist only if we make these things happen.
I think we need to:
1. get better at doing the defense work - right-scope
2. be proactive -
3. help engineering deliver faster - whether through scoping or

activitySummary: The user is actively engaged in composing an email on Gmail. The email is addressed to multiple recipients, including Ben New, Nouman Shah, David Schwartz, Joe Conley, Marcelo Skaba, and Chris Hornby, all from devfactory.com. The subject of the email is 'CEO feedback'. The content of the email discusses various feedback points from the CEO, including the performance of Q2 compared to Q1, the speed of work, and the movement of work to external companies. The email also highlights the importance of addressing product dependencies and improving engineering delivery speed.

The user is utilizing the Chrome web browser to access Gmail. The browser window is active and positioned at the center of the screen. The user has multiple tabs open, indicating a multitasking environment. The email composition window includes recipient and subject fields, a main text area, and various formatting options. The user is focused on drafting a detailed email that addresses critical feedback and outlines necessary actions to improve business operations and product development.
aiUseSummary: The user is utilizing the AI features within Gmail to assist with email composition. The AI tools provide options to help write, formalize, elaborate, shorten, and suggest responses. These features enhance the user's productivity by offering quick and efficient ways to draft and refine email content, ensuring clear and professional communication.
